questions.text: Which of the following is not a contraindication to the procedure shown? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Primigravida

 

The procedure shown is an External Cephalic Version (ECV), a technique used to turn a breech fetus to a cephalic (head-down) position before labor to facilitate a vaginal delivery. While it is generally more challenging to perform ECV in primigravida (first-time pregnant women) due to a tenser abdominal wall, it is not a contraindication. The procedure can still be performed in primigravida with caution and proper monitoring.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta previa: This is a definite contraindication to ECV because the placenta covers the cervix, preventing safe vaginal delivery. Attempting ECV in such cases could cause placental abruption or severe bleeding, necessitating a cesarean section regardless.

 

Option C. Multiple pregnancy: ECV is contraindicated in multiple pregnancies (twins or more) because manipulating one fetus could adversely affect the position of the other, making the procedure unsafe.

 

Option D. Ruptured membranes: When membranes are ruptured, there is a loss of amniotic fluid (liquor), which is necessary for the maneuverability of the fetus during ECV. Without sufficient amniotic fluid, the procedure is difficult, risky, and not feasible.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Primigravida is not a contraindication for ECV, though it may be technically more challenging compared to multiparous women. Key contraindications to ECV include placenta previa, multiple pregnancy, and ruptured membranes.

questions.text: A chronic alcoholic presents with hallucinations, seeing snakes, tremors, disorientation and inability to recognize his own family members, after cessation of alcohol for 2 days due to festive season. Diagnosis? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Delirium Tremens

 

Explanation:


 The case presents classic features of delirium tremens:

  • Occurs after alcohol cessation in chronic alcoholics
  • Onset typically 2-3 days after stopping alcohol
  • Symptoms include: 
    • Visual hallucinations 
    • Tremors
    • Disorientation
    • Confusion and inability to recognize family
  • It's a withdrawal symptom of alcohol

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Wernicke's Encephalopathy Incorrect: Wernicke's encephalopathy is not a withdrawal symptom but results from thiamine deficiency, characterized by:

 

  • Global confusion
  • Ophthalmoplegia
  • Ataxia ("GOA" triad)

 

Option C. Korsakoff psychosis Incorrect: Korsakoff psychosis presents with:

 

  • Amnesia
  • Confabulation
  • No visual hallucinations

 

Option D. Alcoholic Hallucinosis Incorrect: Alcoholic hallucinosis presents with:

 

  • Only auditory hallucinations
  • Noother symptoms occur as mentioned in the question

 

Educational Objective:

 

Symptoms After Cessation of Alcohol Intake

questions.text: In extroversion, what is the yoke muscle of the right lateral rectus muscle? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Left medial rectus

 

The yoke muscle of the right LR is the left MR.

 

Yoke muscles are the primary muscles in each eye that accomplish a given version (eg, for right gaze, the right lateral rectus and left medial rectus muscles).

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Left superior oblique: This muscle is involved in intorsion, depression, and abduction of the left eye, not in coordinating rightward gaze with the right lateral rectus.

 

Option C. Left inferior rectus: This muscle is responsible for depression and adduction of the left eye, not relevant to the rightward gaze.

 

Option D. Left superior rectus: This muscle is involved in elevation and intorsion of the left eye, not in the horizontal movement to the right.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In extroversion (rightward gaze), the yoke muscle for the right lateral rectus (which abducts the right eye) is the left medial rectus (which adducts the left eye), enabling coordinated horizontal movement.

questions.text: A G2 with a previous LSCS underwent cesarean delivery. During surgery, there was excessive bleeding, and a hysterectomy had to be done. The image of the uterus is shown. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Placenta accrete syndrome


Placenta accrete syndrome (PAS) includes conditions where the placenta abnormally attaches to the uterus, such as placenta accreta, increta, and percreta. In this case, the image and description of the uterus with the placenta still attached indicate PAS. The typical presentation involves severe intraoperative bleeding because the placenta does not detach easily from the uterine wall, necessitating an obstetric hysterectomy to control the hemorrhage. This condition is common in patients with a history of cesarean sections (LSCS) due to scarring in the uterine wall, making placental attachment more likely. Diagnosing PAS antenatally can alter management strategies, such as planning an elective upper segment cesarean section between 34-37 weeks and avoiding the lower uterine segment to minimize bleeding and complications. After delivering the baby, the placenta should be left in situ, followed by an immediate obstetric hysterectomy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Placenta previa: Placenta previa occurs when the placenta covers the cervix, leading to painless bleeding during pregnancy but not typically associated with an adherent placenta that requires hysterectomy.

 

Option C. Abruptio placentae: This condition involves premature placental detachment from the uterine wall, leading to painful bleeding. However, it does not involve a placenta that remains attached and does not generally necessitate a hysterectomy.

 

Option D. Rupture uterus: Uterine rupture involves a tear in the uterine wall, often resulting from previous uterine surgeries. It presents with acute pain and significant bleeding, but the description and image do not match the typical findings of PAS.

 

Educational Objective:


Placenta accrete syndrome involves abnormal placental adherence to the uterine wall, often leading to severe bleeding during delivery and requiring obstetric hysterectomy.

choices.text: Decreased action of LPL and increased action of HSL
Increased action of LPL and increased action of HSL
Decreased action of LPL and decreased action of HSL
Increased action of LPL and decreased action of HSL

questions.text: In a patient with diabetes mellitus, the synthesis of TG and VLDL is increased from the liver. What is the cause of the same? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreased action of LPL and increased action of HSL

 

In diabetes mellitus, insulin deficiency or resistance leads to two important enzymatic changes:

 

  1. Decreased activity of Lipoprotein Lipase (LPL) – This enzyme normally converts triglycerides in blood to free fatty acids for storage in adipose tissue
  2. Increased activity of Hormone Sensitive Lipase (HSL) – This promotes release of stored triglycerides as free fatty acids from adipose tissue

 

These changes result in:

 

  • Increased triglycerides in blood due to decreased LPL activity
  • Increased lipolysis and ketosis due to increased HSL activity
  • Overall increase in circulating free fatty acids

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased action of LPL and increased action of HSL: Insulin resistance/deficiency decreases LPL activity

 

Option C. Decreased action of LPL and decreased action of HSL: HSL activity is increased, not decreased in diabetes

 

Option D. Increased action of LPL and decreased action of HSL: This would increase TG clearance and decrease lipolysis, opposite to what occurs in diabetes

 

Educational Objective:

 

In diabetes mellitus, decreased LPL and increased HSL activities lead to increased triglycerides and VLDL synthesis in the liver, contributing to diabetic dyslipidemia.

questions.text: A boy presented with a fever and chills. Rapid test was positive for specific antigen HRP-2. Which of the following species of Plasmodium is the most likely causative agent? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Plasmodium falciparum

 

Patient with given clinical symptoms and the HRP-2 positivity points to diagnosis of P. falciparum malaria.

 

This test is based on the detection of histidine-rich protein-2 (HRP-2), produced only by the asexual forms of Plasmodium falciparum, present on the surface of RBCs. It can detect only Plasmodium falciparum HRP-2 antigen but not the other three species of Plasmodium. Test remains positive until 2 weeks after the cure.

 

 

Another Kit test is Parasite lactate dehydrogenase (p LDH) which can detect all four Plasmodium species that infect humans.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Plasmodium malariae: Not detected by the HRP-2 test.

 

Option C. Plasmodium vivax and Option D. Plasmodium ovale: Also not detected by the HRP-2 test. They would be identified by other rapid tests targeting different antigens like pLDH (Plasmodium Lactate Dehydrogenase).

 

Educational Objective:

 

For a rapid diagnosis of Plasmodium falciparum infection, the detection of the HRP-2 antigen is critical. This test is specific to P. falciparum, aiding in rapid treatment decisions crucial for preventing the severe complications associated with this malaria species.

questions.text: A 56-year-old female patient presented with a history of pathological fracture of the neck of femur. On lab investigations, ALP and N-telopeptide levels were raised. The DEXA scan confirmed the diagnosis as osteoporosis. Based on the lab values of osteoporosis, which other values will be raised in this patient? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Tartrate Resistant Acid Phosphatase

 

In osteoporosis, there is an imbalance between bone resorption (breakdown) and bone formation, with resorption exceeding formation. This leads to bone weakening, which is why the patient has a pathological fracture.

 

The key markers that are elevated in cases of osteoporosis include N & C terminal telopeptides and tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP), which are markers of increased bone resorption. In osteoporosis, TRAP levels are elevated, indicating that bone destruction is occurring at a higher rate than formation.

 

Other markers like ALP (alkaline phosphatase) may also be raised, but the specific marker for bone resorption and the correct answer in this case is TRAP.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Alanine Transaminase: This is a liver enzyme commonly elevated in liver diseases, but it has no direct association with bone metabolism or osteoporosis.

 

Option B. Aspartate Aminotransferase: Like ALT, AST is another liver enzyme, primarily elevated in liver damage and certain heart conditions. It is unrelated to bone resorption or osteoporosis.

 

Option C. Lactate Dehydrogenase: LDH is an enzyme found in many tissues and may be elevated in conditions involving tissue breakdown, but it is not specific to bone resorption or osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Tartrate-resistant acid phosphatase (TRAP) is elevated in osteoporosis due to increased bone resorption, making it a key marker for this condition.

choices.text: Monitor BP and terminate pregnancy if BP rises
Terminate pregnancy at 40 weeks of gestation

questions.text: A 35-year-old primigravida who conceived after in-vitro fertilization therapy came for an antenatal checkup at 38 weeks of gestation. Her obstetric history revealed that she was pregnant with DCDA twins. On examination, the first twin was found to be in a breech position and the maternal blood pressure was found to be greater than 140/90 mm Hg on two occasions with grade 1+ proteinuria. What should be done next? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Immediate Caesarean section

 

  •  The patient is a case of 
    • Preeclampsia 
    • Twin pregnancy (1st twin breech)
  • She is 38 weeks
  • As she is preeclamptic and has crossed 37 weeks, treatment would be to deliver her immediately. 
  • As the 1st twin is non cephalic, the mode of delivery is a cesarean delivery. 
  • Indications of cesarean delivery in multiple pregnancy:        
    • 1st twin non cephalic
    • Monoamniotic monochorionic twins
    • Conjoined twins
    • Triplets and above

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Monitor BP and terminate if BP rises: There is no indication to wait any longer as even in mild pre-eclampsia, delivery is done at 37 weeks. Waiting any longer is simply subjecting both mother and fetus to risks.

 

Option C. Terminate at 40 weeks: Again, this should not be done as in pre-eclampsia, delivery is planned at 37 weeks (mild) and 34 weeks (severe). This patient is already 38 weeks gestation

 

Option D. Induce labor with PGE2 gel: This patient should be delivered by cesarean section as she has twin babies, the 1st of twin is breech (non-cephalic). This becomes an indication for an elective LSCS.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of preeclampsia with twin pregnancies where the first twin is in a breech position at 38 weeks, immediate cesarean section is the recommended course of action.

 

Ref: Page no 1778, Williams Obstetrics, 26th edition

questions.text: Identify the deficiency: (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Vitamin D

 

RICKETS

 

  • In rickets, maturation of osteoid occurs before closure of growth plates, which superimposes the skeletal growth abnormalities i.e., incomplete skeletal calcification and softening of bones.
  • Pathology:
    • Irregular laying of osteoid with widening of osteoid seam and islets into the diaphysis
    • Thin and weak new trabeculae
    • On joint loading, juxta-epiphyseal metaphysis becomes broad and cup-shaped

 

 

  • Causes:
    • Vitamin D disorders: nutritional, secondary, malabsorption, decreased liver (25) hydroxylase activity
    • Calcium deficiency
    • Phosphorus deficiency
    • Renal losses: Fanconi syndrome
    • Tumors associated with rickets: GCT, osteoblastoma, fibrous dysplasia, neurofibromatosis
       
  • Radiographic findings:
    • The characteristic feature of rickets are thickening and widening of growth plate (physis).
    • Indistinct and hazy metaphysis abnormally wide (splaying) with cupping or flaring (Brush-like appearance)
    • Bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices
    • Looser’s zone in 20% cases

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Vitamin C. Scurvy is a condition caused by dietary lack of vitamin C (ascorbic acid), hence is also called hypovitaminosis C. It is characterized by an increased bleeding tendency, impaired collagen synthesis resulting in osteoporosis, and impaired wound healing. It is rarely seen in adults. Young children and elderly are more predisposed to scurvy due to diet or overheating of food. It does not occur before 6 months of age. Patients present with lethargy, malaise, bone pain, bleeding diathesis, and impaired wound healing. Pediatric radiographic features include generalized osteopenia, cortical thinning (pencil-point cortex), periosteal reaction due to subperiosteal hemorrhage, expansion of costochondral junctions (scorbutic rosary), hemarthrosis, Wimberger ring sign (circular, opaque shadow around epiphyseal centers of ossification, due to bleeding).

 

 

Option C. Vitamin A. Hypovitaminosis A results from inadequate intake of vitamin A, fat malabsorption, or liver disorders and produces a variety of epithelial alterations. Radiographic features includes slow bone development, widening of cranial sutures with bulging fontanelles, and skull hyperostosis.

 

Option D. Vitamin E. Hypovitaminosis E is rare. It is usually due to the malabsorption of vitamin E, e.g. cystic fibrosis or pancreatic failure. It manifests as dysfunction of the CNS, characteristically presenting with a tremor and ataxia. Tendon reflexes are often absent. Clinically and radiologically it may be indistinguishable from the neurological sequelae of hypovitaminosis B12, i.e. subacute combined degeneration of the cord (SACD).

 

Educational Objective:

 

Vitamin D deficiency presents as thickening and widening of growth plate (physis); indistinct and hazy metaphysis with abnormally wide (splaying), cupping or flaring (Brush-like) appearance; and bowing of diaphysis, with thinning of cortices.

questions.text: A 17-year-old girl presents to the emergency and is found to have raised blood pressure, tachycardia, diaphoresis, and mydriasis. The mother reports that she saw her consuming a substance in an unknown dose. What is the likely substance? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Cocaine

  

The patient presents with symptoms of sympathetic overactivity, including raised blood pressure, tachycardia, diaphoresis (excessive sweating), and mydriasis (dilated pupils). These symptoms are characteristic of stimulant intoxication, particularly with substances that increase the release of catecholamines, such as cocaine. Cocaine is a powerful central nervous system stimulant that induces a surge of dopamine, leading to intense sympathetic activation, which matches the symptoms described.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Morphine: Morphine is an opioid that causes respiratory and cardiovascular depression, pinpoint pupils (miosis), and reduced sympathetic activity, which is the opposite of what is observed in this case.

 

Option C. Heroin: Like morphine, heroin is an opioid that results in symptoms of sedation, respiratory depression, and miosis, rather than the sympathetic overdrive seen here.

 

Option D. Chlordiazepoxide: Chlordiazepoxide is a benzodiazepine that acts as a sedative and anxiolytic. It would typically cause sedation, hypotension, and muscle relaxation, not the heightened sympathetic response observed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cocaine intoxication is associated with signs of sympathetic overactivity, including elevated blood pressure, tachycardia, diaphoresis, and mydriasis.

choices.text: Lung cancer
Bladder cancer

questions.text: A patient with occupational exposure to benzene presents with repeated infections, easy fatigability, weight loss, and evening rise of temperature. This occupational exposure will predispose him to which of the following cancers? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Leukemia

 

Benzene exposure at work increases the risk of developing leukemia. The clinical history of repeated infections, easy fatigability, weight loss, and evening temperature rise with benzene exposure points to leukemia.

 

Hepatic CYP2E1 converts benzene to an epoxide. The epoxide and other metabolites disrupt bone marrow progenitor cell differentiation, resulting in marrow aplasia and acute myeloid leukemia.

 

Acute myeloid leukemia (AML), acute lymphocytic leukemia (ALL), chronic lymphocytic leukemia (CLL), multiple myeloma, and non-Hodgkin lymphoma have all been linked to benzene exposure.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Lung Cancer: Exposure to arsenic and its compounds, asbestos, beryllium and its compounds, chromium compounds, nickel compounds, radon, and its decay products can cause lung cancer.

 

Option C. Bladder Cancer: Exposure to aryl amines, particularly 2-naphthylamine and related compounds, cyclophosphamide, cigarette smoking, irradiation can cause bladder cancer.

 

Option D. Skin Cancer: Exposure to UV rays, arsenic, and its compounds can cause skin cancer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Occupational exposure to benzene predisposes individuals to leukemia, as benzene metabolites disrupt bone marrow progenitor cell differentiation, leading to marrow aplasia and various types of leukemia. The clinical presentation of repeated infections, easy fatigability, weight loss, and evening rise of temperature in a patient with benzene exposure is highly suggestive of leukemia.

questions.text: A 30-year-old pregnant female is advised to take folic acid supplements. Folic acid is given in pregnancy to prevent which of the following conditions? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Neural tube defects

 

Folic acid supplementation during pregnancy is crucial for the prevention of neural tube defects (NTDs), which are serious birth defects of the brain and spine, such as spina bifida and anencephaly. The neural tube forms early in pregnancy, often before a woman knows she is pregnant, which is why folic acid supplementation is recommended even before conception and during early pregnancy.

 

The recommended daily dose of folic acid for most pregnant women is 400 micrograms, but this dose may be increased to 4000 micrograms in women who are at higher risk for NTDs or are taking certain medications, such as anti-epileptic drugs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anemia: While folic acid can help prevent anemia due to folate deficiency, the primary reason for its supplementation during pregnancy is to prevent neural tube defects, not anemia.

 

Option C. Preeclampsia: Folic acid is not specifically used to prevent preeclampsia. Other interventions, such as calcium supplementation, are more relevant for preeclampsia prevention.

 

Option D. Gestational diabetes: Folic acid does not play a role in the prevention of gestational diabetes. This condition is managed through diet, exercise, and, if necessary, medication.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Folic acid supplementation in pregnancy is essential to prevent neural tube defects, with the standard recommended dose being 400 micrograms per day, increased to 4000 micrograms for those at higher risk.

questions.text: A patient presented with abdominal pain since 4 days with a history of remitting fever and bradycardia after having meals outside frequently. Which test can be done in the patient to confirm the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Blood culture

 

The patient's symptoms of abdominal pain, remitting fever, bradycardia, and a history of eating meals outside suggest a diagnosis of typhoidal salmonella. In the early phase of this infection, particularly within the first week, the most appropriate diagnostic test is a blood culture. Blood cultures are most effective in detecting Salmonella bacteria during the initial week of illness, which aligns with the patient's 4-day history of symptoms. Early detection through blood culture is crucial for initiating appropriate treatment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Widal test: This test is typically performed in the second week of illness when antibodies against Salmonella begin to rise. Since the patient is only 4 days into the illness, the Widal test is not the most reliable at this stage.

 

Option C. Urine culture: Urine cultures may become positive later in the course of typhoid fever, typically in the third or fourth week. It is not useful in the early stages of the disease.

 

Option D. Stool culture: Stool cultures are generally useful in the later stages of typhoid fever, around the third week. They are not as effective for early detection within the first week.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In suspected cases of typhoidal salmonella presenting within the first week of symptoms, a blood culture is the most appropriate diagnostic test.

questions.text: A child presented with hydrocephalus, intracranial calcification, and bilateral chorioretinitis. What can be the most probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Congenital Toxoplasmosis
Congenital toxoplasmosis is classically associated with the triad of hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications, and chorioretinitis. This triad is often remembered as "C3" where C represents chorioretinitis, calcifications (intracranial), and hydrocephalus (cephalus).

Toxoplasma gondii infection in utero can cause these characteristic findings, and they are critical for the diagnosis. These symptoms result from the parasite's effect on the brain and eyes, leading to fluid accumulation (hydrocephalus), calcified lesions in the brain, and inflammation of the choroid and retina.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Congenital Syphilis:  The classical triad of congenital syphilis is represented by "INH" - Interstitial Keratitis, Neurosensory Deafness, and Hutchinson's teeth.

 

 

Option C. Congenital Rubella: The triad associated with congenital rubella includes cataracts, heart disease (often patent ductus arteriosus or other cardiac defects), and neurosensory deafness, summarized as "CHD" (Cataract, Heart Disease, Deafness). It does not involve hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications, or chorioretinitis.

 

 

Option D. Neisseria gonorrhea: Neisseria gonorrhea is a bacterial infection that typically does not present with a triad of symptoms and is unrelated to congenital infections leading to hydrocephalus, intracranial calcification, or chorioretinitis.

 

Educational Objective:


The classical triad of congenital toxoplasmosis includes hydrocephalus, intracranial calcifications, and chorioretinitis, which are key findings for diagnosis.

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy presented with complaints of recurrent bleeding. He has a retroperitoneal hematoma and develops joint pain with swelling on slight exercise.  There is no mucosal bleeding in the patient. Which of the following coagulation factor can be responsible for the patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Factor 8/9 deficiency

 

The presence of recurrent deep tissue bleeding (retroperitoneal hematoma and develops joint pain with swelling on slight exercise) in a male is suggestive of a clotting factor deficiency.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Von Willebrand factor deficiency: Typically presents with mucosal bleeding and prolonged bleeding time, not deep tissue bleeding as described.

 

Option C. Lupus anticoagulant: Usually associated with antiphospholipid syndrome, leading to a paradoxical increase in thrombosis rather than bleeding.

 

Option D. Factor 9/12 deficiency: Factor XII deficiency does not cause significant bleeding and is usually discovered incidentally with prolonged aPTT.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hemophilia, caused by deficiencies in factors VIII or IX, presents with recurrent deep tissue bleeding and hemarthrosis, without significant mucosal bleeding. This differentiates it from other bleeding disorders such as von Willebrand disease.

questions.text: Which factor is associated with the Leiden mutation? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) V

 

Leiden mutation is a single nucleotide mutation that occurs in factor V.

 

Factor V Leiden (FVL) is a point mutation of factor V resulting in an elimination of the cleavage site in factor V and factor Va. Activated protein C, a natural anticoagulant cannot bind and inactivate factor V as there is a mutation in the binding site on factor V for activated protein C. Therefore, as factor V is not inactivated it continues to be active and increases thrombosis risk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. VIII: Factor VIII is involved in the intrinsic pathway of the coagulation cascade and is affected in conditions like hemophilia A. 

 

Option C. I: Factor I, also known as fibrinogen, is a protein involved in the final step of the clotting process, forming fibrin clots.

 

Option D. X: Factor X, part of both the intrinsic and extrinsic pathways, is crucial for the conversion of prothrombin to thrombin.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Leiden mutation specifically affects factor V, rendering it resistant to inactivation by activated protein C, unlike factors VIII, I, or X.

questions.text: An antiemetic was given to a chemotherapy patient, who then developed symptoms such as acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors. Which of the following medications would have resulted in these symptoms? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Metoclopramide

 

  • Metoclopramide is an antiemetic and a prokinetic drug that acts by blocking the D2 receptors. It can be given IV and it can cross the Blood brain barrier, thereby leading to D2 receptor block in the brain which can have side effects like acute dystonia, abnormal movements and drug induced Parkinsonism.
  • In such cases, to treat them, drugs having central anticholinergic action like Benzhexol are used. They work by resorting the balance that has been disrupted by having a relative cholinergic excess in the striatum due to dopaminergic blockade.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ondansetron: Ondansetron is a serotonin 5-HT3 receptor antagonist. It is commonly used as an antiemetic, especially in chemotherapy-induced nausea and vomiting, but it does not cause extrapyramidal side effects like metoclopramide. Its side effect profile mainly includes headaches, constipation, and QT prolongation.

 

Option C. Meclizine: Meclizine is an antihistamine with anticholinergic properties, used primarily to treat motion sickness and vertigo. It does not block dopamine receptors and therefore does not cause extrapyramidal symptoms.

 

Option D. Scopolamine: Scopolamine is an anticholinergic drug used to prevent nausea and vomiting, particularly motion sickness. It works by blocking acetylcholine receptors and does not cause extrapyramidal symptoms. Its side effects include dry mouth, dizziness, and blurred vision.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Metoclopramide, an antiemetic that acts by blocking D2 receptors, can cause extrapyramidal symptoms such as acute dystonia, bradykinesia, and tremors.

questions.text: Injury to which nerve results in absent gag reflex? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) IX & X

 

The gag reflex, also known as the pharyngeal reflex, is a protective mechanism that prevents foreign objects from entering the throat. This reflex involves both sensory and motor components:

 

  • Sensory Component (Afferent): The sensory part of the gag reflex is mediated by the Glossopharyngeal nerve (Cranial Nerve IX). When the posterior wall of the pharynx or the palate is touched, the sensory information is carried by the Glossopharyngeal nerve to the medulla oblongata.
  • Motor Component (Efferent): The motor response, which causes the contraction of the pharyngeal muscles, is mediated by the Vagus nerve (Cranial Nerve X). This nerve provides the efferent pathway, leading to the muscle contraction observed in the gag reflex.

 

Injury to either of these nerves can disrupt the reflex: damage to CN IX affects the sensory input, while damage to CN X affects the motor response, resulting in an absent gag reflex.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A (VII & X): Cranial Nerve VII (Facial nerve) is not involved in the gag reflex. The Facial nerve primarily controls muscles of facial expression and does not play a role in the sensory or motor aspects of the gag reflex.

 

Option C (V & IX): Cranial Nerve V (Trigeminal nerve) is responsible for sensation in the face and motor functions such as biting and chewing, not for the gag reflex. Therefore, its involvement in the gag reflex is incorrect.

 

Option D (VII & IX): While Cranial Nerve IX is correctly identified as part of the reflex, Cranial Nerve VII is not involved. This makes the pairing incorrect.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The gag reflex involves the Glossopharyngeal nerve (CN IX) for sensory input and the Vagus nerve (CN X) for motor response. Damage to either nerve can result in an absent gag reflex.

questions.text: A elderly patient presents with cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy. Which investigation should be performed next to help you diagnose the condition? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. ANCA

 

The clinical features of cutaneous vasculitis, glomerulonephritis, and peripheral neuropathy are suggestive of a systemic vasculitis affecting small vessels. Anti-neutrophil cytoplasmic antibodies (ANCA) are associated with certain types of small vessel vasculitis, making ANCA testing the next appropriate step in the diagnostic process. The presence of ANCA, depending on its pattern—c-ANCA typically associated with granulomatosis with polyangiitis (formerly Wegener’s granulomatosis) and p-ANCA with microscopic polyangiitis and Churg-Strauss syndrome—helps in confirming the diagnosis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. RA factor: Although rheumatoid factor (RA factor) can be elevated in conditions like mixed cryoglobulinemia, which might present similarly, it is less specific for diagnosing small vessel vasculitis compared to ANCA.

 

Option C. HbsAg: Hepatitis B surface antigen (HbsAg) could be relevant if considering hepatitis B associated vasculitis, but given the clinical presentation, it is less likely the cause of these symptoms.

 

Option D. DIF (Direct Immunofluorescence): While useful in diagnosing immune complex deposition diseases such as immune-complex mediated vasculitis, it is not as directly diagnostic of ANCA-associated vasculitis as ANCA testing itself.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Features are suggestive of small vessel vasculitis.

 

 

Reference - Harrison/Vasculitis syndrome/Chap 363

questions.text: Identify the structures marked in numbers.  (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 1-liver, 2-pancrease, 3-spleen

 

Explanation:

 

In the provided CT scan of the abdomen, three structures are marked -

 

  1. The first structure (marked as "1") is identified as the liver. This identification is based on its large size and position on the right side of the vertebral column. The liver is a prominent organ in the right upper quadrant of the abdomen, adjacent to the anterior abdominal wall.
  2. The second structure (marked as "2") is the pancreas. Specifically, this is the head of the pancreas. The pancreas lies in the retroperitoneal space, with its head nestled in the curve of the duodenum and its tail extending towards the hilum of the spleen.
  3. The third structure (marked as "3") is the spleen. The spleen is located in the left upper quadrant of the abdomen, near the stomach and under the left diaphragm. It is typically a crescent-shaped organ.

 

Educational Objective:

questions.text: Which of the following is least likely to occur during a normal pregnancy? (NEET PG 2016)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Elevated systolic blood pressure

 

Elevated systolic blood pressure is least likely to occur during normal pregnancy. In fact, blood pressure typically decreases slightly during pregnancy, with the maximum drop occurring in the second trimester. This physiological change happens despite increased cardiac output because there is a corresponding decrease in systemic vascular resistance (SVR decreases by 21%) and peripheral vasodilation. Blood pressure normally begins to return to pre-pregnancy levels near term.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Increased heart rate: This is a normal physiological change in pregnancy. Heart rate increases by approximately 15-17% during pregnancy, typically rising about 15 beats per minute from baseline. This contributes to the overall increase in cardiac output needed to support the pregnancy.

 

Option C. Increased cardiac output: This is a well-documented normal change in pregnancy. Cardiac output increases progressively by about 40% above non-pregnant levels, reaching its peak around 30-34 weeks. This increase is due to both increased stroke volume (↑25%) and increased heart rate (↑15%).

 

Option D. Increased blood volume: Blood volume increases significantly during normal pregnancy by approximately 40%. Plasma volume increases even more, by about 40-50%, resulting in physiological hemodilution. This expanded blood volume supports the growing fetus and helps protect against blood loss during delivery.

 

Educational Objective:

 

While normal pregnancy causes significant cardiovascular adaptations including increased heart rate, cardiac output, and blood volume, blood pressure typically decreases slightly due to peripheral vasodilation and reduced systemic vascular resistance, making elevated systolic blood pressure the physiological change least likely to occur in normal pregnancy.

questions.text: In Demographic cycle, B curve represents: [NEET PG 2024]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Death rate

 

In the demographic cycle, the B curve represents the death rate (Crude Death Rate - CDR). The demographic cycle is divided into five stages, which are primarily determined by birth and death rates:

 

  1. Stage 1 (High Stationary): Both the birth rate (A) and the death rate (B) are high, resulting in a stable population.
  2. Stage 2 (Early Expanding): The birth rate (A) remains high while the death rate (B) starts to decline due to improved medical facilities, causing the population to increase.
  3. Stage 3 (Late Expanding): Both birth and death rates start declining, often due to the introduction of family planning and other socio-economic factors. India is currently in this stage.
  4. Stage 4 (Low Stationary): Both rates decline to a low level, stabilizing the population growth.
  5. Stage 5 (Declining): The birth rate drops below the death rate, leading to a reduction in population size.

 

In this context, Curve B clearly represents the death rate as it follows the pattern of decline in stages 2 and 3, stabilizes in stage 4, and may increase slightly in stage 5.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Birth rate: Incorrect. Curve A represents the birth rate (Crude Birth Rate - CBR), which remains high initially but starts to decline from stage 3 onwards.

 

Option C. Growth rate: Incorrect. Growth rate is not directly shown on the graph; it is inferred from the difference between birth and death rates.

 

Option D. Total population: Incorrect. Curve C represents the total population, which increases as the death rate declines and stabilizes when both rates are low.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The B curve in the demographic cycle represents the death rate, which declines significantly from stage 2 due to improved healthcare and stabilizes in later stages.

questions.text: A patient presents with infection of the cavernous sinus with involvement of the nerve related on its medial side. To confirm the involvement of the abducent nerve, the patient is asked to look towards: (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Lateral side

 

The abducent nerve (Cranial Nerve VI) innervates the lateral rectus muscle of the eye, which is responsible for moving the eye laterally (away from the midline, or towards the ear). The lateral rectus muscle’s action is essential for lateral gaze. If there is damage to the abducent nerve, the lateral rectus muscle will be paralyzed, leading to an inability to move the eye laterally and resulting in a medial squint (esotropia), where the eye turns inward.

 

To confirm involvement of the abducent nerve, the patient is asked to look towards the lateral side. If the nerve is damaged, the patient will be unable to move the eye laterally, confirming the impairment.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Superior side: Movement of the eye upward (superior gaze) is controlled primarily by the superior rectus muscle, which is innervated by the oculomotor nerve (Cranial Nerve III). This is not the movement tested for the abducent nerve.

 

Option B. Inferior side: Inferior gaze (looking down) involves the inferior rectus and the superior oblique muscles, innervated by the oculomotor nerve and trochlear nerve (Cranial Nerve IV) respectively. This does not test the abducent nerve.

 

Option C. Medial side: Medial movement of the eye is controlled by the medial rectus muscle, which is innervated by the oculomotor nerve. This movement is not used to assess the function of the abducent nerve.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The abducent nerve (Cranial Nerve VI) controls the lateral rectus muscle, which moves the eye laterally. Damage to this nerve results in the inability to move the eye outward, leading to a medial squint (esotropia).

 

Mnemonic – EOM3 SO4 LR6 (all extraocular muscle are supplied by 3rd CN except Superior oblique which is supplied by 4th CN and lateral rectus muscle which is supplied by 6th cranial nerve)

questions.text: All of the following are features of Crohn's disease except: (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Lead pipe appearance

 

The lead pipe appearance is a radiological term typically associated with ulcerative colitis, not Crohn's disease. It describes the appearance of the colon on imaging studies, where the colon becomes tube-like with a loss of haustral folds due to chronic inflammation and fibrosis. This feature reflects the continuous, uniform involvement characteristic of ulcerative colitis.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Transmural involvement: This is a hallmark of Crohn's disease, where inflammation can affect the entire depth of the intestinal walls from mucosa to serosa.

 

Option C. Rectal sparing: Often seen in Crohn's disease, where inflammation may skip the rectum, unlike ulcerative colitis, which almost always involves the rectum.

 

Option D. Perianal fistula: Commonly associated with Crohn's disease due to the deep transmural inflammation that can lead to complications such as fistulas and abscesses, particularly around the anal area.



Educational Objective:

 

 

Reference - Harrison/IBD

questions.text: Which of the following autoantibodies is incorrectl
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C. Anti-LKM3 and Chronic Hepatitis C

 

Explanation:

 

Anti-LKM3 is associated with chronic hepatitis D, not chronic hepatitis C. In the classification of chronic hepatitis, anti-LKM3 antibodies are specifically linked to hepatitis D virus infection, while hepatitis C has different immunologic markers. This represents an important serologic distinction that helps in differentiating between these viral hepatitis types.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Anti-LKM1 and Autoimmune Hepatitis II: This association is correct. Anti-LKM1 (liver-kidney microsome type 1) antibodies are characteristic markers of type II autoimmune hepatitis. These antibodies can occasionally be found in some cases of hepatitis C, but they are primarily diagnostic for autoimmune hepatitis type II.

 

Option B. Anti-LKM2 and Drug-Induced Hepatitis: This association is correct. Anti-LKM2 antibodies are directed against cytochrome P450 enzymes and are characteristically found in cases of drug-induced hepatitis, reflecting the immunologic response to drug-metabolite adducts formed during hepatic injury.

 

Option D. Anti-SLA and Autoimmune Hepatitis Type III: This association is correct. Anti-SLA (antibodies to soluble liver antigen) are specifically associated with autoimmune hepatitis type III, which represents a serologic subcategory of autoimmune hepatitis with distinctive clinical features.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Specific autoantibody profiles serve as important serologic markers that help differentiate between various forms of chronic liver disease - anti-LKM3 is specifically associated with chronic hepatitis D, not hepatitis C, while different LKM autoantibody subtypes have distinct disease associations.

questions.text: Within the framework of Sustainable Development Goal 3, the objective of target 3.1 is to achieve a reduction in the Maternal Mortality Ratio to what specific level (per 1 lakh live birts) by the year 2030? [NEET PG 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) <70

 

In Sustainable Development Goal 3, the target 3.1 aims to reduce the Maternal Mortality Ratio by 2030 to <70 per 1 lakh live births.

 

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

SDGs – Targets & Indicators

 

3.1 - By 2030, MMR < 70

3.2 - By 2030, NNMR 12 & U5MR 25

3.3 - By 2030, end epidemics of AIDS, TB, Malaria and NTDs and combat Hepatitis, Water-borne diseases and other CDS.

3.4 - By 2030, reduce by 1/3 premature mortality from NCDs.

3.5 - Strengthen the prevention & treatment of substance abuse.

3.6 - By 2020, halve the global deaths and injuries form RTA.

3.7 - By 2030, universal access to Sexual & Rep – health care services.

3.8 - Achieve Universal health coverage.

3.9 - By 2030, reduce the number of deaths, illnesses form hazardous chemicals and air, water and soil pollution and contamination.

questions.text: In which of the following is the disc diffusion method for antibiotic susceptibility testing applied? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Kirby-Bauer method

 

The disc diffusion method for antibiotic susceptibility testing is applied in the Kirby-Bauer method.

 

To perform Kirby-Bauer's disc diffusion method, a suitable standard dilution of a broth culture of the test bacterium is inoculated on the surface of a solid medium (Cation-adjusted Mueller-Hinton agar) as a lawn culture. After drying, various antibiotic discs are placed on its surface. Zones of inhibition around the disc are recorded and interpreted according to the zone diameters available in the tables of the Clinical and Laboratory Standards Institute (CLSI) guidelines. The results obtained are qualitative (resistant, sensitive, or partially sensitive).

 

Laboratory testing for antibiotic sensitivity can be done by:

 

  • Diffusion method- Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method, Stokes disc diffusion method
  • Dilution method- broth dilution method, agar dilution method
  • Combination of diffusion and dilution method- E-test (Epsilometer)

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Agar dilution method: This method involves incorporating different concentrations of antibiotics into agar plates. It's primarily a quantitative technique that provides the minimum inhibitory concentration (MIC) of antibiotics.

 

Option C. Broth dilution method: Similar to the agar dilution method but performed in a liquid medium. This method also determines the MIC of antibiotics.

 

Option D. PCR based assay: This molecular method detects the presence of specific antibiotic resistance genes but does not directly test the susceptibility of bacteria to antibiotics.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Kirby-Bauer disc diffusion method is a straightforward and widely used technique for assessing bacterial antibiotic susceptibility, providing vital information for the appropriate selection of antibiotics in clinical settings. It is essential for effective antimicrobial stewardship and the management of bacterial infections.

choices.text: Give shock with 2 J/kg and check pulse
Give shock with 2 J/kg and continue CPR for 2 mins
Continue CPR till pulse is back

questions.text: A 2-year-old child is undergoing CPR. He is pulseless and shows the below ECG. What is the next step? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Give shock with 2 J/kg and continue CPR for 2 mins

 

The ECG shown in the image is indicative of ventricular tachycardia . Pulseless VT is a life-threatening condition that requires immediate defibrillation. The appropriate treatment for VT during CPR is to deliver an unsynchronized shock (defibrillation) at an initial dose of 2 J/kg. After delivering the shock, it is crucial to immediately resume CPR for 2 minutes before reassessing the rhythm and pulse, as this maximizes the chances of successful resuscitation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Give shock with 2 J/kg and check pulse: This option is incorrect because checking the pulse immediately after delivering the shock wastes valuable time. The correct protocol is to immediately resume CPR after the shock, without pausing to check the pulse, as this enhances the likelihood of restoring circulation.

 

Option C. Synchronized cardioversion: Synchronized cardioversion is used for treating certain types of arrhythmias, such as supraventricular tachycardia (SVT) or atrial fibrillation (AF), but it is not appropriate for pulseless ventricular tachycardia. In pulseless VT , unsynchronized defibrillation is required.

 

Option D. Continue CPR till pulse is back: This option is partially correct but incomplete. While continuing CPR is essential, the most crucial intervention in the case of pulseless VT is defibrillation. Without delivering a shock, the chances of survival are significantly diminished.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

In a pediatric cardiac arrest with pulseless ventricular tachycardia on the ECG, the correct immediate action is to defibrillate with 2 J/kg and continue CPR for 2 minutes before reassessing.

questions.text: Which part of scaphoid is most susceptible to avascular necrosis? (NEET PG  2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Proximal 1/3rd

 

SCAPHOID FRACTURE

 

  • Salient features: 

    • It is the most commonly fractured bone in the carpus, in adult as well as children. 

    • Most commonly in males between the ages of 15 and 30. 

    • Fullness and tenderness in anatomical snuff box. 

    • Proximal pressure along the axis of the thumb may be painful.

  • Most common location:              

    • Adults and adolescents: Middle third (Waist) fractures (70%) > proximal pole fracture (20%) > distal pole fracture (10%). 

    • Children: Distal pole avulsion type fracture.

  • Pathogenesis of AVN:

    • Most of the blood supply to the scaphoid enters distally, so blood supply of scaphoid diminishes proximally. 

    • This accounts for the fact that 1% of distal third, 20% of middle third, 40% of proximal third and 100% of proximal pole fractures result in avascular necrosis or non-union of the proximal fragment.

    • Thus, the proximal third of the scaphoid is most susceptible to avascular necrosis (AVN) due to its precarious retrograde blood supply. 

    • Fracture in the waist (middle third) can disrupt this blood flow to the proximal fragment, leading to AVN.

  • Diagnosis: 

    • A wrist sprain that is sufficiently severe to require radiographic examination initially should be treated as a possible fracture of the scaphoid, and radiographs should be repeated in 2 weeks even though initial radiographs may be negative.

    • Recent fracture shows only in the oblique view.

    • MRI can diagnose occult fractures.

    • MRI, especially with gadolinium enhancement, also is useful in assessing the vascularity of a fractured scaphoid.

  • Treatment:

    • Nondisplaced, Stable Scaphoid Fractures: Scaphoid Glass Holding Cast.

    • Displaced, Unstable Scaphoid Fractures: Headless Screw (Herbert) is used

    • Complication: Non-union > Avascular Necrosis

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Distal 1/3rd. Distal 1/3rd portion of the scaphoid is a well vascularized area, so fracture to this part is often undisplaced or minimally displaced, thus they heal faster with conservative management. This portion of scaphoid is fractured in 10% of cases. AVN of this part occurs in 1% cases. 

 

Option B. Middle 1/3rd. Middle 1/3rd or the waist of scaphoid is most commonly fractures, accounting for 70% of cases. But the chances of AVN at this portion are around 20%. 

 

Option D. Scaphoid tubercle. Avulsion fracture of scaphoid tubercle are rare. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The proximal 1/3rd portion of the scaphoid have less chances of fracture (20%) but have higher chances of AVN (40%).

questions.text: MEN 1 syndrome is associated with:(FMGE 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Parathyroid tumor

 

MEN 1 (Multiple Endocrine Neoplasia Type 1) syndrome is associated with the development of tumors in endocrine glands, particularly the parathyroid glands, pituitary gland, and pancreatic islet cells. This syndrome is sometimes referred to as the "3 P" syndrome, referring to the involvement of the parathyroid, pituitary, and pancreas.

 

Parathyroid tumors, specifically parathyroid adenomas or hyperplasia, are a characteristic feature of MEN 1 syndrome. These tumors lead to the overproduction of parathyroid hormone (PTH), resulting in primary hyperparathyroidism.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Parotid tumor: Tumors of the parotid gland are not typically associated with MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Option B. Hepatocellular cancer: MEN 1 syndrome is not directly linked to the development of hepatocellular cancer (liver cancer).

 

Option C. Pheochromocytoma: Pheochromocytoma, a tumor of the adrenal gland medulla, is associated with MEN 2 syndrome, not MEN 1 syndrome.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In MEN 1 syndrome, the classic endocrine gland tumors involved are parathyroid tumors (leading to hyperparathyroidism), pituitary adenomas, and pancreatic islet cell tumors (such as gastrinomas and insulinomas). Remembering the "3 P" association (parathyroid, pituitary, and pancreas) can help recall the key features of this syndrome.

 

Familial Syndrome associated with Pheochromocytoma and Extra-adrenal Paragangliomas:

choices.text: Nothing as the child is already exposed

questions.text: Anuj has been diagnosed with diphtheria and is being treated in the ward. His 3-year-old brother, Ajay who lives in the same house has received vaccination against diphtheria about 16 months back. What is the next best step for the management of the younger sibling, Ajay? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Erythromycin only

 

In this case, the close contact of the patient is a 3-year-old child who had received the diphtheria vaccination 16 months ago, most likely as the 4th dose (1st booster). Therefore, only erythromycin is needed for prophylaxis.

 

It is crucial to monitor all household contacts for 7 days and obtain cultures from their nose and throat. Regardless of immunization status, all contacts should receive antibiotic prophylaxis such as benzathine penicillin G or erythromycin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. One booster dose: This is not necessary because the child had received the diphtheria vaccination 16 months ago, which should still provide adequate immunity.

 

Option B. Nothing as the child is already exposed: This is incorrect because close contacts need to be managed to prevent the spread of diphtheria, and antibiotic prophylaxis is recommended.

 

Option C. Erythromycin + diphtheria toxoid: This option is for those who have received less than three doses of diphtheria toxoid or have an unknown vaccination history. Since Ajay has been recently vaccinated, only erythromycin is needed.

 

Educational Objective:

 

When Additional Toxoid is Needed:

  • <3 doses total received
  • >5 years since last dose
  • Unknown vaccination history
     

For a close contact of a diphtheria patient who has received the diphtheria vaccination within the last five years, antibiotic prophylaxis with erythromycin is the appropriate management step.

choices.text: NLEP, leprosy has a vaccine available
NLEP, Leprosy is curable, reduce stigma, spread awareness

questions.text: The image of the mascot ‘Sapna’ shown below and identify what does she represent in the national health program: (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) NLEP, Leprosy is curable, reduce stigma, spread awareness

 

'Sapna' is the mascot of National Leprosy Eradication Program (NLEP) in India. She represents the success story of leprosy treatment, as she herself was a leprosy patient who got completely cured after taking multi-drug therapy (MDT). Her role is to spread awareness about:

 

  • Curability of leprosy through MDT
  • Reducing stigma and discrimination associated with leprosy in society
  • Encouraging early detection and treatment seeking behavior
  • Demonstrating that leprosy patients can lead a normal life after treatment

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. NLEP, leprosy has a vaccine available: Incorrect because there is no widely accepted vaccine for leprosy currently available for public use

 

Option B. NLEP, Leprosy has been eliminated: While India achieved elimination status (<1 case/10,000 population) in December 2005, the program continues as new cases still occur

 

Option D. NLEP, leprosy can't affect children: Incorrect as leprosy can affect people of any age group including children

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Sapna is the mascot of NLEP who represents successful treatment of leprosy and aims to reduce stigma while spreading awareness about curability of the disease through multi-drug therapy.

choices.text: Physiological hernia failing to go back

questions.text: Which of the following best explains the embryological basis for the formation of an omphalocele? ( NEET PG 2019 )
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Physiological hernia failing to go back

 

  • Omphalocele is characterized by the herniation of abdominal viscera through an enlarged umbilical ring.
  • Amnion protects the viscera, which may include the liver, small and large intestines, stomach, spleen, or gallbladder.
  • The defect is caused by the bowel's failure to return to the body cavity after its physiological herniation between the sixth and tenth weeks.

 

 

Omphalocele is associated with other congenital anomalies (e.g., trisomy 13, trisomy 18, or Beckwith-Wiedemann syndrome) and with increased levels of alpha-fetoprotein (AFP).

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Excessive length of the intestine: During early embryonic development, the intestines do grow at a rapid pace, leading to temporary herniation of the midgut into the umbilical cord around the 6th week. This is called physiological midgut herniation. The intestines then rotate and usually return into the abdominal cavity by the 10th week. It's not the excessive length of the intestine itself that causes omphalocele; rather, it's the failure of the intestines (and sometimes other organs) to return to the abdominal cavity.

 

Option C. Herniation of liver: While the liver can indeed be one of the organs present in an omphalocele, its herniation is not the primary cause of omphalocele. Instead, it is a consequence of the failure of the physiological hernia to return to the abdominal cavity. In larger omphaloceles, the liver is more commonly seen as part of the herniated content.

 

Option D. Herniation of umbilicus: This option is not precise. The umbilicus itself is not what herniates in omphalocele. Instead, it's through the region of the umbilicus that the intestines and possibly other organs herniate out into the umbilical cord during development. If they fail to return to the abdomen, an omphalocele forms.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Omphalocele is primarily caused by the failure of the physiological hernia of the midgut to return to the abdominal cavity during fetal development, not merely by the excessive length of the intestine or specific organ herniation.

questions.text: When two variables demonstrate a strong positive correlation, what is the value of their coefficient of correlation? [NEET PG 2015]
questions.solution:
Ans. (c) +1

 

  • The correlation coefficient (r) is bounded between -1.0 and +1.0. When examining the relationship between two variables, a value of r approaching +1 indicates a strong positive association. 
  • This means when one variable increases, the other variable also increases proportionally, creating a direct relationship that characterizes strong positive correlation.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. -1: This value represents a strong negative correlation, where one variable increases as the other decreases. When r is near -1, it indicates that the variables move in opposite directions.

 

Option B. 0: When r = 0, it indicates no association between the variables. There is no linear relationship present when the correlation coefficient is zero.

 

Option D. +2: This value is impossible for a correlation coefficient. The correlation coefficient r must lie between -1.0 and +1.0. Any value outside this range is mathematically invalid. 

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correlation coefficient (r) must fall within the range of -1 to +1, with +1 representing perfect positive correlation where both variables move proportionally in the same direction.

questions.text: Identify the instrument:  (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Maddox rod

 

The above instrument is a Maddox rod.

 

A Maddox rod is a specially constructed device, consisting of a series of parallel cylinders, that converts a point source of light into a line image. It can be used to test for horizontal and vertical deviations, and when used in conjunction with another Maddox rod, for cyclo deviations.

 

Maddox Rod Test

 

Patient is asked to fix on a point light in the centre of Maddox tangent scale at a distance of 6 metres. A Maddox rod (which consists of many glass rods of red colour set together in a metallic disc) is placed in front of one eye with axis of the rod parallel to the axis of deviation.

 

 

 

Due to dissimilar images of the two eyes, fusion is broken and heterophoria becomes manifest. The number on the Maddox tangent scale where the red line falls will be the amount of heterophoria in degrees.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Maddox wing: An instrument used to measure the horizontal and vertical deviations at near using a different mechanism involving a scale and moving wings.

 

Option B. Maddox glass: This term is not commonly used; it might refer to the Maddox rod or Maddox wing.

 

Option D. Phoropter: An instrument used in refraction testing to determine eyeglass prescriptions, consisting of multiple lenses that can be rotated into place to assess visual acuity and lens power.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Maddox rod is an instrument consisting of parallel cylindrical lenses used to convert a point light source into a line image, aiding in the diagnosis of horizontal, vertical, and cyclo deviations in ocular alignment.

choices.text: It is a large-caliber arteriole situated beneath the mucosa of the gastrointestinal tract
It hemorrhages through a tiny mucosal erosion
It is most frequently found on the greater curvature of the proximal stomach
It is also referred to as a persistent caliber artery

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding a Dieulafoy's lesion is NOT accurate? (NEET PG 2015)
questions.solution:
Correct Answer:  C. It is most frequently found on the greater curvature of the proximal stomach.

 

Explanation:

 

A Dieulafoy's lesion is an uncommon but important cause of gastrointestinal bleeding. While these lesions do occur in the stomach, they are not predominantly found on the greater curvature of the proximal stomach. Dieulafoy's lesions can occur throughout the GI tract, with the most common location being the lesser curvature of the stomach, particularly within 6 cm of the gastroesophageal junction.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. It is a large-caliber arteriole situated beneath the mucosa of the gastrointestinal tract: Dieulafoy's lesions are characterized by abnormally large submucosal arterioles that can erode through the overlying mucosa and cause bleeding.

 

Option B. It hemorrhages through a tiny mucosal erosion:  Dieulafoy's lesions bleed through small mucosal defects or erosions, making them sometimes difficult to detect endoscopically when not actively bleeding.

 

Option D. It is also referred to as a persistent caliber artery: Dieulafoy's lesions are sometimes called "persistent caliber arteries" because they maintain their large diameter as they approach the mucosa, rather than tapering normally.

 

Educational Objective: 

 

Dieulafoy's lesions are an important cause of GI bleeding characterized by large submucosal arterioles that bleed through small mucosal defects, and are most commonly found on the lesser curvature of the stomach rather than the greater curvature.

questions.text: Serotonin is also known as? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) 5-hydroxytryptamine

 

  • Serotonin is 5-hydroxytryptamine. It is produced in the brain, mast cells, platelets and gastrointestinal tract mucosa.
  • Tryptophan is first hydroxylated by tryptophan hydroxylase. The co-enzyme is tetrahydrobiopterin. The tetrahydrobiopterin is regenerated using NADPH.
  • In the next step, 5-hydroxytryptophan is decarboxylated to 5-hydroxytryptamine (5HT), (serotonin). The enzyme, decarboxylase requires pyridoxal phosphate.
  • The effect of serotonin is dependent on the amount of serotonin available at the synaptic site. Part of the serotonin released is again taken up (reuptake). Selective serotonin reuptake inhibitors (SSRI) are widely used in the treatment of psychiatric disorders
  • Monoamine oxidase (MAO) converts serotonin to 5-hydroxyindoleacetic acid (HIAA). MAO will oxidatively deaminate compounds having an amino group attached to a carbon atom. MAO inhibitors (e.g., iproniazid) will cause mood elevation.

 

Clinical correlation:

 

CARCINOID SYNDROME

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. 5-hydroxytryptophan: This is a precursor to serotonin, involved in its biosynthetic pathway, but not the same as serotonin.

 

Option C. 5-carboxytryptamine: This compound does not exist in serotonin’s metabolic pathway and is unrelated to its structure or function.

 

Option D. 5-carboxytryptophan: This is also not part of the serotonin synthesis or its structure; it is a hypothetical derivative that does not have a role in serotonin’s biological actions.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Serotonin, also known as 5-hydroxytryptamine, is a crucial neurotransmitter synthesized from tryptophan and involved in numerous physiological processes. Its synthesis involves specific enzymatic actions that are targeted pharmacologically to manage various psychiatric

questions.text: A 16-year-old boy is admitted with fever, icterus, conjunctival suffusion, and hematuria for 15 days. Which serological test should be done for diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Microscopic agglutination test

 

History of fever with liver and kidney involvement should arouse suspicion for leptospirosis (Weil's disease).

 

A microscopic agglutination test is used for the diagnosis of leptospirosis.

 

Serotype-specific tests:

 

  • Microscopic agglutination test
  • Macroscopic agglutination test

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Widal test: Incorrect, the Widal test is used to diagnose typhoid fever, which involves testing for antibodies against Salmonella typhi antigens but does not present with the same symptom profile as described.

 

Option C. Weil Felix reaction: Incorrect, this test is historically used for diagnosing rickettsial infections, which are caused by different organisms and have different clinical features.

 

Option D. Paul Bunnell test (monospot test): Incorrect, this test is used to diagnose infectious mononucleosis caused by the Epstein-Barr virus, characterized by symptoms like fever, sore throat, and swollen lymph nodes but not typically associated with icterus or hematuria.

 

Educational Objective:

 

 The Microscopic Agglutination Test (MAT) is crucial for diagnosing leptospirosis in patients presenting with symptoms like fever, jaundice, red eyes, and hematuria, as it accurately detects the presence of antibodies against Leptospira, confirming the infection.

choices.text: Hymen does not rupture because opening is too small to allow penis to enter
The hymen does not rupture because Hymen is situated deep inside

questions.text: If a young female child is raped, the hymen is usually: (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Both a and b

 

Rape on Children:

 

In rape of a young female, the hymen is usually not ruptured because of two reasons:

 

  • Vaginal opening is very small, hence penetration very difficult. Usually, the penis is placed either within the vulva or between the thighs. And as such, only redness and tenderness of vulva may be caused.
  • Hymen is deeply situated, hence even if some penetration occurred, it is not ruptured.

 

Also, in a child, there may be no signs or very few signs of general violence since the child has no idea of the act and is also unable to offer resistance.

 

However, in rare cases of great violence, the penis may be forcibly introduced, causing rupture of the vaginal vault, Hymen and associated visceral injuries. In this case the injuries will be more severe than adults and such injuries might result in death.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In cases of rape involving a young female, the hymen is usually not ruptured because the vaginal opening is very small, making penetration difficult, and the hymen is situated deeply. Additionally, children may not show signs of general violence due to their inability to resist, though severe injuries can occur in cases of great violence.

questions.text: What significant error did the intern make while creating a banner on measures to prevent the spread of non-communicable diseases, as assigned by a group of doctors?  (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Shift from PUFA to trans-fat

 

The significant error made by the intern while creating the banner on measures to prevent the spread of non-communicable diseases was the recommendation to "Shift from PUFA to trans-fat."

 

The other options, such as banning smoking in public areas, restricting alcohol selling/consumption, and decreasing additive salt on food, are appropriate measures to prevent non-communicable diseases.

 

However, the shifting from polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) to trans-fats is incorrect, as trans-fats are one of the important risk factors for the development of non-communicable diseases. The recommendation should be to reduce trans-fat intake and promote the consumption of healthier fats like PUFA.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ban smoking in public areas - This option is correct and should be included in the banner, as smoking is a major risk factor for non-communicable diseases.

 

Option B. Restrictions on alcohol selling/consumption - This option is correct and should be included in the banner, as alcohol consumption is a risk factor for conditions like coronary heart disease and hypertension.

 

Option D. Decrease additive salt on food - This option is correct and should be included in the banner, as even prudent diet (a diet for dietary goal achievement) says the salt intake should be <5gm/day.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The significant error made by the intern was recommending a shift from polyunsaturated fatty acids (PUFA) to trans-fats, as trans-fats are known to increase the risk of non-communicable diseases, contrary to the goal of preventing their spread.

questions.text: A child presents to the clinic with fatigue, joint pain, swollen gums. Physical examination reveals fatigue on her skin. Which of the following can be given to treat her condition?  (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Vitamin C

 

Explanation

 

The clinical presentation of fatigue, joint pain, swollen gums, and specific skin manifestations such as perifollicular hemorrhages is characteristic of vitamin C deficiency, known as scurvy.

Scurvy occurs due to inadequate intake of vitamin C (ascorbic acid), which is essential for collagen synthesis. Collagen is a critical component of connective tissues, and its deficiency leads to weakened blood vessels, poor wound healing, and the symptoms observed in scurvy.

 

Key clinical features of scurvy include:

 

  • Fatigue: Generalized weakness and tiredness due to impaired energy metabolism.
  • Joint pain: Due to bleeding within joints and weakened connective tissues.
  • Swollen gums: Gingival swelling, bleeding gums, and dental issues.
  • Skin manifestations: Perifollicular hemorrhages and petechiae due to fragile blood vessels.

 

The treatment for scurvy is supplementation with vitamin C, which will help restore collagen synthesis and resolve the symptoms.

 

 

Other Options

 

  • Option A. Vitamin D: Deficiency in vitamin D typically presents with symptoms related to bone health, such as rickets in children and osteomalacia in adults, rather than the symptoms described here.
  • Option C. Vitamin A: Vitamin A deficiency primarily affects vision (night blindness), immune function, and skin health. It does not typically cause the symptoms described.
  • Option D. Vitamin E: Vitamin E deficiency is rare and usually presents with neurological symptoms and hemolytic anemia, not with the symptoms described in this case.
 

Educational Objective

 

Vitamin C deficiency (scurvy) presents with fatigue, joint pain, swollen gums, and specific skin manifestations. Treatment is supplementation with vitamin C.

questions.text: Combined OCPs are least protective for? (FMGE JAN 2025)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Breast Ca

 

Combined OCPs provide protective effects against several gynecological conditions. However, they offer minimal to no protection against breast carcinoma. Combined OCPs are only protective against benign breast diseases like fibroadenoma, but not against breast cancer.

 

 

Other Options: 

 

Option A. PID (Incorrect)

 

  • Combined OCPs provide significant protection against Pelvic Inflammatory Disease (PID)
  • The thickened cervical mucus and other mechanisms help prevent ascending infections

 

Option B. Endometrial Ca (Incorrect)

 

  • Combined OCPs offer strong protection against endometrial cancer
  • The hormonal effects help prevent endometrial hyperplasia and subsequent cancer risk

 

Option C. Ovarian Ca (Incorrect)

 

  • OCPs provide substantial protection against both benign and malignant ovarian diseases
  • The suppression of ovulation and other mechanisms contribute to this protective effect

 

Educational Objective:

 

While combined oral contraceptive pills provide protection against several gynecological conditions (PID, endometrial cancer, ovarian cancer), they do not provide significant protection against breast cancer.

questions.text: Which type of amputation is shown in the image? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Below knee amputation

 

The image shows an amputation where both the tibia and fibula are visible below the knee, which indicates a below-knee amputation. A dissected specimen of the tibia and fibula below the knee was shown, which matches the image provided. Below-knee amputations involve removing the lower limb while preserving the knee joint, improving the potential for prosthetic use and mobility in the patient.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Above knee amputation: This amputation occurs above the knee joint, where the entire knee and part of the femur are removed. However, the image does not show the knee joint being amputated.

 

Option C. Chopart’s amputation: This type of amputation occurs in the intertarsal region of the foot, which is not applicable in this image, as the amputation is clearly higher up, below the knee.

 

Option D. Lisfranc amputation: This refers to an amputation at the tarsometatarsal joint, which is also a lower limb amputation but located in the foot. The image shows an amputation above the foot, making this option incorrect.

 

Different types of amputations:

 

  1. Hip disarticulation: Removal at the hip joint (disarticulation from the joint).
  2. Above knee amputation: Removal above the knee.
  3. Knee disarticulation: Amputation through the knee joint.
  4. Below knee amputation: Removal below the knee.
  5. Syme's amputation: Amputation above the ankle.
  6. Boyd's or Pirogov amputation: Involves cutting the calcaneum (heel bone).
  7. Chopart's amputation: Involves the intertarsal area (just above the calcaneum).
  8. Lisfranc's amputation: Involves the tarsometatarsal joint (between the tarsal and metatarsal bones).
  9. Transmetatarsal amputation: Amputation in between the metatarsal bones.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A below-knee amputation involves the removal of the lower limb below the knee joint, preserving the knee, tibia, and fibula, which improves mobility and function compared to an above-knee amputation.

questions.text: Identify the class of immunoglobulin shown in the image below. (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Ig A

 

The above image shows a dimeric structure, characteristic of secretory IgA.

 

IgA immunoglobulin is the major antibody responsible for mucosal immunity. Its serum levels are usually low. It is predominantly present in the extravascular secretions. It is present in secretions such as milk, saliva, and tears, and in secretions of the respiratory, intestinal, and genital tracts.

 

When present in the serum, it exists as a monomer similar to IgG. However, when it is secreted, it exists as a dimer. The dimeric structure consists of two monomers, which are stabilized by two additional polypeptides:

 

  • ﻿﻿J chain, which stabilizes the molecule.
  • ﻿﻿Secretory component, which is incorporated into the IgA when transported through the epithelial cell.

 

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Ig G: Typically exists as a monomer and is the most abundant immunoglobulin in the blood and extracellular fluid.

 

Option C. Ig M: The largest antibody, mainly in pentameric form, being the first antibody to be produced in response to an infection.

 

Option D. Ig E: Involved in allergic reactions and parasitic infections, known for its role in the immune response to allergens.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Secretory IgA is critical for mucosal immunity due to its unique structure and location. It acts as the first line of defence by preventing pathogens from adhering to and penetrating mucosal surfaces, thus playing a vital role in protecting the body from infections, especially at the mucosal barriers.

questions.text: Identify: (NEET PG 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans.  B) Venous ulcer

 

The correct answer is Venous ulcer. Venous ulcers, also known as ulcers of varicose veins, typically occur on the medial aspect of the lower leg, just above the medial malleolus. They are often found in the "gaiter" area and are associated with chronic venous insufficiency. The ulcers are usually shallow with irregular borders, and the surrounding skin may show signs of venous stasis, such as hyperpigmentation and edema. The presence of varicose veins and the ulcer's location on the medial side strongly indicate a venous origin.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ischemic ulcer: Ischemic ulcers are generally located on the tips of toes, pressure points, or other areas that experience reduced blood flow. They have well-defined borders and a punched-out appearance. The location and presentation in this case do not match ischemic ulcers.

 

Option C. Trophic ulcer: Trophic ulcers are usually associated with neuropathy, often seen in diabetic patients. They occur on pressure points such as the plantar surface of the foot and are characterized by a loss of protective sensation. The location above the medial malleolus does not fit with trophic ulcers.

 

Option D.  Infectious ulcer: Infectious ulcers can occur anywhere on the body and are characterized by overt signs of infection like pus, redness, and warmth. While infection can complicate venous ulcers, the primary cause in this case is venous insufficiency, not infection.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Venous ulcers are typically found on the medial aspect of the lower leg, above the medial malleolus, and are associated with chronic venous insufficiency. Recognizing their characteristic location and appearance is crucial for diagnosis.

questions.text:
LMN lesions are associated with? (INICET NOV 2024)

 

  1. Decrease in muscle tone
  2. Spastic paralysis
  3. Babinski positivity
  4. Fasciculations
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 1, 4

 

Lower motor neuron (LMN) lesions are characterized by two features:

 

1. Decreased in muscle tone (flaccidity) – Due to interruption of the normal reflex arc

 

4. Fasciculations – Spontaneous twitching of muscle fibers due to denervation

 

Other Options:

 

2. Spastic paralysis is a characteristic of upper motor neuron (UMN) lesions

 

3. Babinski positivity sign (upgoing plantar response) is also a feature of UMN lesions

 

These features occur due to loss of inhibitory signals from upper motor neurons, which is not the case in LMN lesions

 

Educational Objective:

 

Lower motor neuron lesions are characterized by:

 

  1. Decreased muscle tone (flaccidity)
  2. Fasciculations (muscle twitching)
  3. Absence of spasticity and Babinski sign (which are UMN signs)
