questions.text: Patient develops severe migratory joint pain after an attack of acute rheumatic fever. How will you manage this patient? (FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Aspirin

 

Explanation

 

The correct answer is Aspirin. Acute rheumatic fever commonly presents with migratory polyarthritis, which is characterized by severe joint pain that moves from one joint to another.

 

The treatment of choice for this arthritis is nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs (NSAIDs), with aspirin being the most effective and commonly used. Aspirin helps to reduce inflammation and pain associated with the arthritis of acute rheumatic fever.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Furosemide: This is a diuretic and is not used for the management of arthritis in acute rheumatic fever. It may be used in cases of heart failure associated with rheumatic carditis.

 

Option B. Digoxin: This is a cardiac glycoside used in heart failure and atrial fibrillation. It is not used for managing arthritis in acute rheumatic fever.

 

Option D. Amiodarone: This is an antiarrhythmic medication and has no role in the management of arthritis in acute rheumatic fever.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The primary treatment for severe migratory joint pain (arthritis) in acute rheumatic fever is the use of NSAIDs, with aspirin being the drug of choice due to its effectiveness in reducing inflammation and pain.

questions.text: A ten-year-old boy was brought to the OPD with fever and swelling of hands after playing football. He gives a history of previous episodes of swelling of hands. On imaging, his spleen was found to be shrunken. Which of the following is a likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Sickle cell anemia

 

History is suggestive of dactylitis precipitated by playing causing microvascular obstruction. Shrunken spleen suggestive of auto splenectomy with recurrent episodes of dactylitis suggests sickle cell anemia.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Malaria: Typically presents with cyclical fever, chills, and splenomegaly rather than a shrunken spleen. The history of recurrent hand swelling isn't typical for malaria.

 

Option C. Pancreatitis: Main symptoms include severe abdominal pain, nausea, and vomiting, unrelated to the symptoms described in the case.

 

Option D. Measles: Characterized by a rash, fever, cough, conjunctivitis, and Koplik spots, none of which relate to the symptoms described.

 

Educational Objective:  

 

In a child presenting with fever and recurrent hand swelling following physical activity, alongside a history of a shrunken spleen, sickle cell anemia should be considered a primary diagnosis. This highlights the importance of considering hemoglobinopathies in patients with peculiar skeletal pains and organ findings suggestive of chronic hemolytic processes.

 

Reference - Harrison 21 /Hemoglobinopathies/Chapter 98

choices.text: ﻿﻿﻿Saline infusion sonography

questions.text: A female patient has a history of three miscarriages. Identify the investigation that was done from the image shown below? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hysterosalpingography

 

  • This is an image of a Hysterosalpingogram (HSG)
  • An HSG is used to
    • Delineate uterine anomalies.
    • Endometrial cavity lesions like polyps, adhesions
    • Tubal patency in infertility

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Hysteroscopy: Hysteroscopy appears like this image. Using fluid media to distend the uterine cavity, a hysteroscope can visualize the inside of the uterine cavity.

 

 

Option B. Saline infusion sonography: Saline infusion sonography: This is an ultrasound-based investigation, wherein saline is injected in the uterine cavity and this helps detect intra-uterine space occupying lesions and appears like this:

 

 

Option D. Transvaginal ultrasound: This appears like this:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

A Hysterosalpingogram (HSG) is an X-ray procedure used to delineate uterine anomalies, identify endometrial cavity lesions, and assess tubal patency in cases of infertility.

 

Ref: Page no 588, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6th edition

choices.text: Examination in chief

questions.text: During the court proceedings, the defense lawyer asks a leading question, which the prosecutor appeals against. The judge grants the appeal. Leading questions are not allowed in all of the following except? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Cross examination

 

In Cross examination, leading questions are allowed to challenge the witness's testimony and credibility.

 

Leading Question:

 

  • Leading questions in law are questions asked by lawyer, to a witness, with the goal of "putting words in the mouth of the witness," to achieve a desired response or result.
  • Answer to leading question can be given in “yes” or “No”
  • Example:
    • Has Ram killed shyam? It is a leading question.
    • Who has killed shyam? It is not a leading question
  • IEA related to leading questions are 141, 142 and 143 IEA (Indian Evidence Act).

 

Other Options

 

Option A. Re-examination: Follow-up questioning by the party who called the witness, after cross-examination. In this leading questions are not allowed to ensure the witness's own account is clarified or points raised during cross-examination are rebutted without leading the witness.

 

Option C. Examination in Chief: The initial questioning of a witness by the party who called them. Leading questions are not permitted to ensure the witness's testimony is their own and not influenced by the questioner.

 

Option D. Dying Declaration: A statement made by a person who believes they are about to die, concerning the cause or circumstances of their death. Leading questions are not allowed to ensure the statement is voluntary and not influenced, preserving its reliability.

 

Educational Objective

 

Leading Questions are Not permitted in:

 

  1. Examination in chief
  2. Re-Examination
  3. Dying Declaration

 

Leading Questions are permitted in:

 

  1. Cross Examination
  2. Dying Deposition
  3. Hostile witness is an exception wherein the leading questions can be asked even in examination in chief
